docs.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal editorial page disapproves of Chicago's plan "to impose a hyper-minimum wage on 'big-box' retail stores with more than $1 billion of sales. The new law will require the likes of Wal-Mart, Target, Costco and Home Depot to pay every worker - regardless of experience, education or skill - a minimum wage of $13 an hour by 2010 ($10 in salary and $3 in health benefits)." The Journal continues:

headline.main: The Impact of the Minimum Wage

docs.abstract: Editorial writers and economists debate the real effects of the minimum wage.
docs.snippet: Editorial writers and economists debate the real effects of the minimum wage.

docs.lead_paragraph: The past 100 years has seen a change from small, sickly people to humans who are so robust their ancestors are almost unrecognizable.

headline.main: So Big and Healthy Grandpa Wouldn’t Even Know You
headline.print_headline: So Big and Healthy Nowadays That Grandpa Wouldn’t Even Know You

docs.snippet: The past 100 years has seen a change from small, sickly people to humans who are so robust their ancestors are almost unrecognizable.

docs.lead_paragraph: MARK and Kirsten McDowell's favorite place for dinner with their four children is the Whole Foods Market in Jericho, N.Y. Some weeks they buy prepared foods and eat in the 100-seat cafe at the front of the supermarket three nights in a row. ''It's convenient,'' said Ms. McDowell, a full-time mother from Merrick who can't always fit cooking into her children's hectic schedules. ''It's replaced fast food for us. This is a way to have the healthiest food you could have quickly.''
docs.abstract: Article on new amenities and services at supermarkets in New York metropolitan area, including coffee bars, sushi bars, cafes, alfresco dining areas, full-service restaurants, baby-sitting services, entertainment and nutrition seminars, as they seek to distinguish themselves from competitors; changes at Whole Food Markets, Stop & Shop and Stew Leonard's described; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As part of a trend to make food shopping less of a chore, supermarkets now sport coffee bars, sushi bars, cafes, al fresco dining areas and full-service restaurants.

headline.sub: From Sushi to Singing Bananas, Stores Race to Offer More  ;

docs.snippet: As part of a trend to make food shopping less of a chore, supermarkets now sport coffee bars, sushi bars, cafes, al fresco dining areas and full-service restaurants.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two groups have produced a report about the corrosive effect of short-term thinking in American business. But long-termism can be just as much a problem as short-termism.
docs.snippet: Two groups have produced a report about the corrosive effect of short-term thinking in American business. But long-termism can be just as much a problem as short-termism.
